user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_SocketGetInfo(osal_id_t sock_id, OS_socket_prop_t *sock_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;
    int32               return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(sock_prop);

    memset(sock_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_socket_prop_t));

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_stream_table, token);

        strncpy(sock_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(sock_prop->name) - 1);
        sock_prop->creator = record->creator;
        return_code        = OS_SocketGetInfo_Impl(&token, sock_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketGetInfo:
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME]; /**< @brief Name of the socket */
    osal_id_t creator;               /**< @brief OSAL TaskID which opened the socket */
} OS_socket_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_stream_table
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_MAX_API_NAME 20
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the lines that call string.h functions need investigation for Rule 21.17. The other code fragments do not invoke string handling functions and therefore are not relevant to this rule: the parameter check (OS_CHECK_POINTER) only tests for NULL, the object lookup (OS_ObjectIdGetById), table access (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET), the assignment to sock_prop->creator, the call to OS_SocketGetInfo_Impl, OS_ObjectIdRelease, and the function return do not perform any operations from <string.h> and thus do not risk string-buffer out-of-bounds accesses under Rule 21.17.
